item.title: A Ministry of Presence
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
January 25, 2015

Many of us are first drawn to a church community during a time of transition in our lives. A loved one dies, we're going through a divorce, we want our children to have a liberal religious education. At first, we attend the "church of the me" only getting our own needs met. Soon we discover that being in beloved community means our presence is needed to minister to others. No longer satisfied with just getting our needs met each Sunday, we come to church to serve.

item.title: Why Selma Matters
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
January 18, 2015

Mark Morrison-Reed writes, "For Unitarian Universalism, whose most progressive elements had long been champions of freedom in its broadest sense, Selma was a test." Fifty years ago, Unitarian Universalists were challenged to answer Dr. King's call and show up in Selma. Many did; two died. What was Selma's impact on our religious movement? What do the events of fifty years ago mean to us today when the streets of our country are filled with people holding signs proclaiming "black lives matter?"

item.title: Beloved Community
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
January 11, 2015

As Unitarian Universalists we strive to create beloved community - a community where love is present. It sounds simple enough, but most of us hear the struggle behind the label, the complexity lurking just below the surface. Still we strive; we dream dreams and we have visions.

item.title: Love Came Down at Christmas
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
December 21, 2014

The story of Christ's nativity makes sense on a mythological level. Joining the story of one lowly-born in a manger among the animals with the stories of other gods and heroes celebrated at the time of the Winter Solstice makes mythological sense. In the nineteenth century poet Christina Rossetti wrote, "Love came down at Christmas, love all lovely, love divine," capturing the essence of our deep yearning for the transcendent.

item.title: Mystery and Wonder
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
December 14, 2014

The gift of this time of year is to be reminded to gaze at our lives through the eyes of a child. We are reminded of mystery and wonder and the potential for joy in the smallest moments. Remaining open, we allow ourselves to be immersed in the darkness of the shortest days of the year and with faith we wait for the light to reappear.

item.title: The Work of Loving the World
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
December 7, 2014

The sermon description goes here."My work is loving the world," writes the poet Mary Oliver. It is easy to love the world of the poet: "the phoebe, the delphinium, the sheep in the pasture, and the pasture." It is difficult to love the world when it is torn apart by injustice, especially when we are unable to come to consensus as to what justice looks like. Our work is to love the world, no matter what.

item.title: The Gospel According to Kurt
item.description:
by Merlin Snider
November 30, 2014

Gospel is one of those words that do double duty. It means a life story, like the gospels in the Bible. It also means some incredibly important kernel of truth. The "gospel truth." Fellowship member Merlin Snider tells the tale of how in graduate school he found the life and work of Kurt Vonnegut, self-described as "simultaneously a humorist and a serious novelist." Like Billy Pilgrim, his famous character from Slaughterhouse Five, Vonnegut came unstuck in time because of the horrible things he had witnessed, and in Vonnegut's heroic, anti-heroic way, managed to describe our human condition with dark humor, compassion, and ultimately hope.

item.title: Gratitude and Reverence
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
November 23, 2014

Gratitude and reverence are important to humanist teachings. Reverence is not just about a feeling associated with a deity. Meister Eckhart supposedly said, “If the only prayer you say in your life is thank you that would suffice.” Cicero’s quote works better for those who don’t pray: “Gratitude is not only the greatest of virtues, but the parent of all others.” Reason does not preclude gratitude and reverence, particularly during this time of year.

item.title: A Letter to My Ex-husband the Atheist
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
November 16, 2014

My ex-husband the atheist has become a character in several of my sermons, serving as a foil to my pious religiosity. First of all, I am not really piously religious and secondly my ex-husband the atheist is more than a character in my sermons. But he has railed against religion enough on his Facebook feed that I feel that I must finally respond with this letter.

item.title: A Humanist Language of Reverence
item.description:
by Rev. Lora Brandis
November 9, 2014

In 2003 when William Sinkford, then the president of our denomination, preached a sermon calling for UUs to reclaim a vocabulary of reverence including the word God, it made the national news. Religious language doesn’t have to mean we use the word God, but it does mean that we have to consciously select how we speak to each other as members of a religious community.
